customer_addr:
2400 John Brantley Boulevard
Terminal 2, RDU
Raleigh, NC 27560
site_name: Trego-Dugan Aviation - RDU - Raleigh-Durham International Airport

citations.narrative:
A Trego-Dugan (T-D) employee was observed accepting a dog for air transport during an inspection conducted at the
Alaska Airlines (AA) ticket counter at Terminal 2, Raleigh-Durham International Airport. The dog was then transported to
another handler, registered as G2 Secure Staff, as oversized baggage for the TSA check and delivery to the secure
baggage holding area below. Per the one Alaska Airlines (AA) on-site point of contact, possession of the dog would then
be transferred back to T-D in the secure baggage area for holding and loading on the Alaska Airlines plane at the
appropriate time. For the week following this inspection, the inspector made multiple requests for the registration
information from T-D. T-D first submitted the Alaska Airlines registration and then another number that is not a valid
USDA registration number. Handling animals in an airline terminal and on the tarmac without the required regulatory
oversight can lead to unregulated handling of animals, putting the animals at risk of unnecessary behavioral stress,
trauma, escape, physical harm or loss of life.
Per the on-site AA and T-D representatives, T-D is an independent business entity that is contracted to AA to conduct
their ticket counter activities and the accepting and handling of animals to be transported on the AA planes at RDU.
The regulations require that each carrier and intermediate handler register with the Secretary by completing and filing a
properly executed form which will be furnished, upon request, by the Deputy Administrator.
Conducting regulated activity without a valid registration violates the Federal Animal Welfare Act.
No regulated activity can be conducted until a valid registration certificate is issued by USDA Animal Care.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with ______.
n

narrative:
2.25(a)  Critical
   
Requirements and procedures. 
A Trego-Dugan (T-D) employee was observed accepting a dog for air transport during an inspection conducted at the 
Alaska Airlines (AA) ticket counter at Terminal 2, Raleigh-Durham International Airport. The dog was then transported to 
another handler, registered as G2 Secure Staff, as oversized baggage for the TSA check and delivery to the secure 
baggage holding area below.  Per the one Alaska Airlines (AA) on-site point of contact, possession of the dog would then 
be transferred back to T-D in the secure baggage area for holding and loading on the Alaska Airlines plane at the 
appropriate time.  For the week following this inspection, the inspector made multiple requests for the registration 
information from T-D.  T-D first submitted the Alaska Airlines registration and then another number that is not a valid 
USDA registration number.  Handling animals in an airline terminal and on the tarmac without the required regulatory 
oversight can lead to unregulated handling of animals, putting the animals at risk of unnecessary behavioral stress, 
trauma, escape, physical harm or loss of life.  
 
Per the on-site AA and T-D representatives, T-D is an independent business entity that is contracted to AA to conduct 
their ticket counter activities and the accepting and handling of animals to be transported on the AA planes at RDU.

The regulations require that each carrier and intermediate handler register with the Secretary by completing and filing a 
properly executed form which will be furnished, upon request, by the Deputy Administrator. 
 
Conducting regulated activity without a valid registration violates the Federal Animal Welfare Act.   
 
No regulated activity can be conducted until a valid registration certificate is issued by USDA Animal Care. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with ______. 
 
 n
